utterance: JW: One of the mechanisms, and I don't know, Raphael, I heard you might work in mineralization. So one of the things that it's known to be able to do is help to bring the magnesium out of, you know, so if you have a mine tailing waste, you know, and it's got magnesium in it. Often sometimes the magnesium isn't necessarily reactive because it's bound in a silica structure and it's very difficult to get it out. But when you add oxylate or oxalic acid to the solution, it actually helps to dissolve the magnesium and make it reactive for crystallization or mineralization with CO2. And so one of the things like Opus 12 was looking at is working with a company called Solidia. And so very different, but looking at Solidia's process, I don't know if you guys know, Solidia is a company where they make low carbon concrete ultimately. And so one process in which they do that is instead of curing with water, they cure with CO2. And it turns out that if you add oxalic acid in that process, you enhance the uptake of CO2 through the curing process. And so really it's like, you know, that acid allows the magnesium atoms in your feedstock, if it's a mineralization approach, to be more reactive to CO2 and to help bind it. But it would be towards a permanent product, not necessarily like a feedstock like you wouldn't use it as a fuel. You would use it as a part of an enhancement process for mineralizing CO2. So that that's how I see it.

utterance: SMS: Based on my understanding of the ways in which we can convert CO2, I know there's a huge push towards electrochemistry because there is that that's one sustainable way of leveraging solar and wind to convert to electricity and then use that towards reducing CO2. One of the things that is kind of less explored, at least based on my understanding, is using light directly. So one of the things that you can achieve with light, which is difficult to achieve in an electrochemical process, is the one electron reduction of CO2. When you talk about electrochemistry, you're talking about two or more electron reduction of CO2, right? Because one electron has a very, very high overpotential associated with it. So those kind of reductions can be achieved using photoredox chemistry. So essentially using light to drive a photoredox catalyst to become an anion and that anion can push one electron towards CO2. And as far as I understand it, there are operational issues associated with it, which is why as of right now, it's mostly focused on highly specific applications. It could either be things like adding COH groups to aromatics. So basically carboxylates styrene and make a polymer precursor, attach a carboxylic acid to an amine and make an amino acid which can go into pharmaceuticals. So there are a lot of specialized applications that we can think of. The challenge, of course, being making sure that these catalysts are cyclable and coming up with continuous processes. But at least there are lab scale continuous processes that exist now that leverage these light assisted pathways. So I think we can do more difficult chemistry as well beyond what is shown with electrocatalysis. And we can think beyond formic acid, right? Because you can use any kind of substrate and link a carboxylate group to it.

annotations.present new idea: The speaker introduces the idea of using light directly for CO2 conversion, highlighting the potential of photoredox chemistry to achieve one-electron reduction, which is difficult in electrochemistry, thus presenting a novel approach.
annotations.expand on existing idea: The speaker expands on the discussion of CO2 conversion methods by detailing the advantages of photoredox chemistry, its applications in specific reactions like carboxylating styrene or forming amino acids, and the challenges associated with catalyst cyclability and continuous processes, building upon the earlier discussion of electrocatalysis.
annotations.provide supporting evidence: The speaker supports the idea of using light directly by mentioning the existence of lab-scale continuous processes that leverage light-assisted pathways, providing evidence for the feasibility of this approach.
annotations.explain or define term or concept: The speaker explains the concept of one-electron reduction of CO2 and its relevance to photoredox chemistry, contrasting it with the two-or-more electron reduction in electrochemistry and defining the role of photoredox catalysts in driving the reaction.
annotations.express alternative decision: The speaker suggests exploring light-driven photoredox chemistry for CO2 conversion as an alternative to the more commonly pursued electrochemistry, and also suggests thinking beyond formic acid as a product.

utterance: SMS: Yeah. So one of the issues that I see with some of the catalysts that we look at is the cyclability. Because you're using light, in addition to doing the photoredox chemistry, these things, these molecules tend to degrade rather rapidly. So you get five turnovers and everything dies out. And this is some, and the issues that I think are kind of common between the materials used for catalysis and the materials we use for organic LEDs, for example. So I think there is a lot of opportunity in trying to identify what those degradation pathways are and finding ways to mitigate them. And then that has applications across all kinds of light, all kinds of photonic materials, not just photoredox chemistry.

utterance: RS: And on this CO2 to food again, it ties into that idea of the remote locations that there might be might be places where it makes sense to produce food in a greenhouse, capture the CO2 from the air, but there's not might not be any CO2 big CO2 source nearby. utterance: AH: Aquaponics you see economies of scale. So the bigger your operation is, the more um environmentally or the least less environmentally impactful they are and the more economical they are. So a lot of the small ones fold in the US. utterance: AF: Yeah, I think there's some issues with the bacterial scaling just because the density of culture bacterial cultures unless you engineer the organisms to to grow to higher density, you can't get as much biomass in a vat of bacteria. annotations.expand on existing idea: The speaker is expanding on the previously discussed topic of using bacteria for CO2 conversion and food production, elaborating on the challenges related to scaling bacterial cultures due to density limitations.

utterance: RG: because it's not something that I'm really familiar with. Um these like pumping CO2 into the ground type things, how permanent is that or does it tend to leak back out?

annotations.ask clarifying question: RG is asking a question about the permanence of pumping CO2 into the ground, indicating a need for clarification on this topic that has been previously mentioned.

utterance: JW: So so if it's in a depleted oil and gas reservoir, uh the the CO2 trapping mechanism is really the same as what's been trapping the oil and gas for millions of years. And so the likelihood of it leaking back out is pretty negligible. Um we've been doing projects like that in in the Permian Basin in Texas since 1972 and there's been zero leakage and zero accidents of CO2. So it's it's pretty good. But at the same time, those are the projects that are such controversial topics because they also as Fang said, like that's not the answer. Uh you're releasing, you know, more CO2 in the form of burning crude oil in the end. And so if there were opportun but it doesn't mean you can't use depleted oil and gas wells to to store CO2. It's just that can we do that and not take more oil out of the ground because those formations are really appropriate for carbon storage. The saline aquafers are another option, but the the difference is is we have to characterize them better, we have to know more about them because they don't necessarily have say a low permeability cap rock that will keep the CO2 physically trapped initially. Um so they just require a lot more characterization. Yeah. And and people, I think a big part of this is just public acceptance and whether or not every culture or community is um comfortable with the idea of putting carbon dioxide, you know, underground in their backyard. And I think that that's another issue.

annotations.provide supporting evidence: The speaker explains the CO2 trapping mechanism in depleted oil and gas reservoirs, stating it's the same mechanism that trapped oil and gas for millions of years, and mentions projects in the Permian Basin since 1972 with zero leakage to support the claim that leakage is negligible.

annotations.express alternative decision: The speaker acknowledges the controversy around using depleted oil and gas reservoirs for CO2 storage because it can lead to more CO2 release from burning crude oil, suggesting that storing CO2 without extracting more oil is a better approach.

annotations.expand on existing idea: The speaker expands on the idea of underground CO2 storage by introducing saline aquifers as another option, but notes they require more characterization due to the lack of a low permeability cap rock.
